entry.title: Re: MANAGE REPAYMENT REQUEST APP NOT FOUND
entry.content:
Hello @FabioSpulveda 

The Manage Repayment Requests app (F5754) appears in the Fiori Apps Library for S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, but it is part of FI-CA Contract Accounts Receivable and Payable.

FI-CA is not part of the standard Finance scope; it is only available if scope item 5D2 – Convergent Invoicing and FI-CA  , or a related industry package, is activated. If that scope is not included in your subscription, the app will not appear.

Review scope items in Manage Your Solution, and if needed, request activation through the CBC /SAP contact.

SAP Help – Contract Accounts Receivable and Payable (FI-CA) Overview

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How to send Data (Integration) from SAP Datasphere to...
entry.content:
Hello Ahmed,

You cannot connect SAP Datasphere directly to GRDC. GRDC only receives data from S/4HANA Cloud through communication scenario SAP_COM_0241 or via file uploads.

In Datasphere, to enable GRDC to access the data, you must first load it into S/4HANA Cloud, using methods such as the Journal Entry – Post API or the Group Reporting APIs. Afterwards, GRDC retrieves the data from S/4.

Alternatively, export your data from Datasphere as a CSV file and upload it into GRDC using a data collection task.

The Application Server field in Datasphere should point to your S/4HANA Cloud API URL (e.g., https://<tenant>.s4hana.cloud.sap). The disabled features in your connection setup are expected, because Datasphere → S/4 connection is designed for reading and writing via OData, not for GRDC integration.

To verify integration, review the Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0241 in S/4 for status and logs, and execute a test package in GRDC to confirm data fetch.

Please inform me if you require any further assistance.

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: MANAGE REPAYMENT REQUEST APP NOT FOUND
entry.content:
Dear @FabioSpulveda , 

please check the following steps: 

 

  • Check the Manage Your Solution app: In your Fiori launchpad, go to the Manage Your Solution app. Search for the scope item: Look for the Accounts Payable scope item (J60) in the list of activated business processes. If this scope item is not active, submit a request to SAP to activate it. 
  • The Manage Repayment Request app is a specialized tool. To access it, you need to be assigned a business role that includes the relevant business catalog. I had already a look and made for you a screenshot below with the business catalog.
  • Even with the correct scope item and role, the app may not appear due to other system settings. If you have the correct role but still can't find the app, it might be due to a custom business role that doesn't include the necessary catalog or a misconfigured launchpad

 

Thank you and BR

Dilan

entry.title: Re: Manual GL Account Assignment for Billing Transactions
entry.content:
Hello @mbanggo 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, It is not possible to alter the reconciliation account when creating a supplier invoice referencing a PO or through the Create Supplier Invoice app (F0859). The reconciliation account is always obtained from the supplier master record and cannot be manually overridden.

The only case where an alternative G/L can be chosen is in direct FI postings, Post Supplier Invoice-Manage Supplier Invoices for Accounts Payable Accountant F0859  – FB60 equivalent. Since these are not subledger-managed postings.

Reference: SAP Help – Supplier Invoice Processing (Public Cloud)

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Automatic addition of 1<>1 in queries when no data is returned in prompts (BO 4.3)
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am using SAP BusinessObjects 4.3 Webi reports and observed the following behavior:

- My report contains multiple queries that rely on a Customer ID prompt.
- When I enter a Customer ID that has no corresponding data, in some of the queries the WHERE clause automatically gets "1<>1" appended.
- This does not happen in all queries, only in some.

I understand that this might be a mechanism to prevent unintended results, but I would like to clarify:

1. Is this behavior officially documented by SAP?
2. Is there a recommended approach to handle prompts so that "1<>1" is not automatically added?
3. Are there best practices for handling queries with potentially empty result sets in BO 4.3?

Attached are screenshots showing the SQL generated with and without data.

Thank you in advance for any guidance or insights!

entry.title: Re: SOAP API for inbound delivery updates
entry.content:
Hello @kdv3 

Batch split creation is not available in the Inbound Delivery, Read, Update (A2X) API. While the API allows updating headers and items, it does not support batch split operations.

In Public Cloud, batch splits must be managed through Fiori delivery apps or by using an extension (BAdI/BTP) after the delivery is created.

Batch Management-SAP Help 

Inbound Delivery (A2X)  

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: ASSIGN PURCHASING ORGANIZATION TO COMPANY CODE
entry.content:
Hello @jerrysam 

Yes, you can reverse the plant–purchasing organisation assignment, but it affects info records, contracts, open POs, and sourcing. Existing documents with the old assignment stay valid, while new ones follow the new mapping.

Before moving to Production, test in Q/Test.

  • Create new POs and verify sourcing and pricing.
  • Validate contracts, scheduling agreements, and vendor purchasing organisation data.
  • Run MRP to confirm sourcing functions correctly.
  • Verify the financial institution's postings and approvals.

Assigning Plant to Purchasing Organisation-SAP Help 

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Split Valuation in SAP MM
entry.content:
Prezados colegas,

Faço parte do tempo de implementação do SAP/4Hana desde janeiro de 2025 e atualmente o projeto está na terceira onda que deverá integrar todo o grupo a nível Brasil com a mesma base do SAP.

Na primeira onda optamos por realizar uma avaliação dividida para determinados tipos de materiais, a partir das instruções da consultoria contratada, e na época fomos avisados ​​que uma vez ativada essa função seria irreversível para o material.

No entanto, devido à legislação tributária brasileira, temos uma lista de códigos de origem de material. Em vários casos, um mesmo código de produto cadastrado pode variar entre as várias origens, dependendo do negócio concretizado.

A partir dessa lógica, a Requisição de Compra emitida pelas áreas Requisitantes envolve as informações dos Dados Mestres de Materiais de maneira automática. No entanto, a confirmação da origem do material ocorre somente na fase de Cotação e Negociação pela equipe de Compras .

Os códigos de origem do material vão de 0 a 9, e um mesmo produto pode variar entre vários desses códigos dependendo da origem do BP e da composição do produto.

A equipe de Compras recebe as requisições das áreas e somente após consultar o mercado definir qual fornecedor tem custos e, por fim, após aprovação das melhores condições definir o código de origem do material para emitir o Pedido de Compra .

Sabemos que  ao solicitar uma avaliação dividida no material, o campo origem do material fica travado/bloqueado para edição nas transações ME21N, ME22N, ME51N, ME52N onde a equipe de Compras utiliza para formalizar a compra de mercadorias através de Pedidos de Compras e Contratos . Desta forma, tantos pedidos de compras emitidos pela ME21N ou alterados pela ME22N, como Contratos de Fornecimento WK/MK emitidos via ME51N ou alterados via ME52N não possuem o campo de origem do material habilitado para conciliar a informação conforme negócio finalizado junto com a BP.

Com base nesse bloqueio, consultamos o SAP e verificamos que há uma Nota SAP que recomenda não editar quando há split valuation Standard ativado. Além disso, verificamos no QAS a possibilidade de reconfigurar esse campo (torná-lo editável) via SHD0, e chegamos à conclusão de que não permite reconfigurar justamente por esse Note SAP.

Queremos uma solução rápida para essa falha no processo de Aquisição, através de uma melhoria nas transações supracitadas que se adequem à legislação brasileira para atender não somente ao nosso projeto, mas para  todos os clientes SAP no Brasil. Pois o impacto negativo ao negócio é enorme e a melhoria traria flexibilidade aos usuários de Compras e maior assertividade nos negócios junto à BP, evitando retrabalhos nos dados mestres, alterações constantes em Pedidos de Compras e Contratos, atrasos nas transações de estoques e conciliações nos objetos de custos, além de riscos de atrasos de pagamentos das compras realizadas.

Estamos à disposição para testar em massa essa melhoria através do SAP/4Hana.

Fico grato pela atenção.
Rodrigo Vieira de Carvalho

entry.title: Re: Error en aplicación Nota 3613078
entry.content:
Hola Comunidad

Algunos de ustedes aplicaron la opción 2 de la nota 3613078, en mi caso particular en periodo quincenal 19.2025 aplique 3 faltas como la constante CKINF esta en cero el descuento lo hace por el total de días y eel empleado es solvente para este descuento.

En periodo 20.2025 hace recalculo a periodo 19.2025 y en periodo 20.2025 regresa lo que desconto en 19 y calcula el descuento a 16 días lo cual es correcto.

Mi duda es por que regresa /381 que descontó correctamente en periodo 19

el /381 tiene en vista V_T51P6 B 2 4 como lo sugiere la nota.

Espero y alguno de ustedes me pueda apoyar.

Saludos

entry.title: Deleting double postings after mapping data through Data Actions
entry.content:
@N1kh1l Hello all,

I load data through CSV file where Func Area and Plant = #. I have made this data action to map combinations to correct Func Area (I dont care about Plant) looking up budget data from last year. It maps correctly, however the old combinations stays there. I have tried saving the data before mapping on a variablemember and a if statement that deletes if input = temp version. However, there are sometimes a few new combinations that wasnt there last year in budget Version. I don't want to delete them. With this method, I delete them also unfortunately.

Do anyone have an idea, where I only delete the old combinations (that is still on func area = # ) that have been mapped? Or better, dont make double transactions.

@N1kh1l  ?

CONFIG.HIERARCHY.INCLUDE_MEMBERS_NOT_IN_HIERARCHY = [d/FUNC_AREA], [d/COST_CENTER], [d/PROFIT], [d/Plant], [d/GL_ACCOUNT]

//SCOPE
MEMBERSET [d/Date] = [d/Version].[p/From_Date] TO [d/Version].[p/To_Date]
MEMBERSET [d/Measures] = ("Amount_LC")

VARIABLEMEMBER #TEMP OF [d/Version] 
VARIABLEMEMBER #TEMPBUDGET OF [d/Version]

AGGREGATE_DIMENSIONS = [d/Plant]
AGGREGATE_WRITETO [d/Plant] = "#"

//DATA WRITING
DATA() = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Version] = "public.Input", [d/FUNC_AREA] = "#")
* (RESULTLOOKUP([d/Version] = "public.Budget", [d/Date] = PREVIOUS(12,"MONTH")) / RESULTLOOKUP([d/Version] = "public.Budget", [d/Date] = PREVIOUS(12,"MONTH")))

entry.title: Re: Add the custom field I added to the sales order to th...
entry.content:
Hello @dogukanpadel 

My Inbox and workflow apps don’t allow Adapt UI, so the message is expected. To display your custom field YY1_AvansMiktar, you need to

  • Publish the field in the right business context (done).
  • Extend the workflow context via Manage Workflow Scenarios or a Custom CDS View/Data Source Extension.
  • Adjust the workflow form template so the field appears in My Inbox.

You must extend the workflow data model and form template.

Let me know how it goes

My Inbox(F0862) 

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: EXTERNAL JOIN when using temporary tables
entry.content:
Did you implement my code to add the links back in? If so what were the results?

Running in debug mode and look at the specific details in each property in the Connection info may give you an idea at what point the links are being removed.

To explain why, CR Designer is a Development tool so it has a lot of internal routines the SDK doesn't have so CRD can resolve a lot of potential issues.

The SDK is based on BOE/CR Server, it assumes what you are publishing/using is 100% accurate. In other words don't use reports that have formulae not used, links and tables that are not used etc.

So when you open a report using the SDK it too assumes all is correct. The issues appear when you change data sources to something that the Engine has problems with, As I said previously TEMP table have never been supported due to permissions, indexes, field mapping and even the DB Clients may introduce problems.

CRQE is the database engine, it connects to the Client and sends various API's to get the info from the Server, possibly something in there is deleting the Links, or at least something CR can't resolve so it removes them. In most cases if CR SDK has issues with the client, missing connection info for example, CR SDK simply fails to connect.

Calling VerifyDatabase() can cause this mis-info to propagate to the connection property bag.

Using ReplaceConnection() and RAS is a must when changing the DB info, the Engine/shared is not capable of the finer details, that's why using Clone() in my sample code is a must, it copies the low level property bag of the existing connection info.

I'm curious, if you set location to the temp tables in CR Designer, save the report and then use it in you app does it keep the Links?

All I can suggest is rather than using SQL's TEMP table make them permanent and simply dump the data into them before setting location, you must match the data structure the original report used, otherwise SDK is going to complain. Database, Tables and Field Names must match 100%.

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite – Generative AI based Integration Flow Generation with Mediation Steps
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Integration Suite - Cloud Integration version 6.96.**, comes with an enhancement on Generative AI (GenAI) feature - GenAI based Integration Flow Generation with Mediations Steps.  This feature is an extension to GenAI based Integration Flow Generation as described in https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-integration-suite-generative-ai-based-integration-flow-generation/ba-p/13761166 . This feature will be available only in SAP Integration Suite Cloud Integration Premium Editions, on specific regions/data centres. This blog or product document will be updated with the list of regions/data centres once the rollout of this feature/software completes. 

This feature is forecasted to rollout in mid-September 2025 (these are tentative timelines, subjected to change as per internal phased rollout plan).

Enabling GenAI Based Integration Flow Generation feature

As tenant administrator of your premium edition tenant, you need to enable this feature in Settings page of SAP Integration Suite. Compared to steps mentioned in the earlier blog https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-integration-suite-generative-ai-based-integration-flow-generation/ba-p/13761166, there is an enhancement in the settings page and the GenAI settings have been moved to a dedicated sub-navigation item called Artificial Intelligence, screenshot of which has been provided below. To enable this feature, you need to agree to the relevant terms and conditions.

Below are the sample screenshots of the same

Note : Flow Step Recommendations is a AI (ML) related feature which was/is available in all editions of Integration Suite. It is a alway's ON feature and tenant administrator will not be able to switch it OFF.  For more information, checkout the blog post https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-cloud-integration-flow-step-recommendations/ba-p/13474550 

 

 

Generating Integration Flows with Mediation Steps

Once this feature is switched ON by the tenant administrator, you - as integration developer persona - can use this feature to generate integration flows. 

Now, you click on Add -> Integration flow menu in your package view, you will be given option for generating the integration flow with assistance from AI or create integration flow manually. 

Below are the screenshots of generating integration flows using generative AI.

If you observe the above screenshot, the description contains information about the components of the integration flow along with systems. This is the extension compared to previous feature version, wherein the generative AI backend layer recognises the components - also known as mediations steps - and generates the integration flow accordingly. 

Once the description is complete, click on send button.

The feature extension now also provides a detailed AI Response on what it has identified as systems, components and actions - kind of a reasoning - with which it will proceed for the integration flow generation. Click on Generate button. Below is the sample output of the generated integration flow.

As you can observe above screenshot, the generated integration flow has the flow steps which matches the components/mediation steps information provided in the integration flow requirement description as user input, along with that, integration flow is auto  aligned/auto formatted. The generative AI backend layer has provided proper names to flow steps/mediation steps as per the description, unlike static names like content modifier 1, message mapping 1 , which you might have observed when you manually drag-and-drop the flow elements and rename them - saves your time a lot. 

It has also generated resources, i.e., message mapping file for the message mapping flow step.

Currently, the generative AI backend layer is only generating empty/default resources., e.g., the generated message mapping file doesn't contain source and target schema structure as shown in the below screenshot.

The relevant resources's content like message mapping with schemas, groovy scripts with custom logic shall be supported in next upcoming increments. 

Summary

SAP Integration Suite – Cloud Integration GenAI based integration flow generation with mediation steps feature will help you bootstrap and accelerate the integration development activity.

As mentioned in the summary section of previous blog https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-integration-suite-generative-ai-based-integration-flow-generation/ba-p/13761166 , this feature extension enhances the generative AI offering with mediations steps. Having said that, all is not complete yet. We noticed accuracy issues sometimes/in some cases - as with LLMs - in our internal validation. Some of the observations are : missing accuracy in generated integration flow and its mediation steps names/sequence connections, missing discovered UCL system's configuration with outbound adapters (please check previous blog on UCL approach in GenAI based Integration flow generation) and flow steps, empty/default resources like message mapping, groovy scripts, missing auto alignment/auto formatting, missing semantic connections for control flows (e.g. router, multicast) of generated integration flow.

We continue working on fixing accuracy issues as we make future releases, but the current extension in GenAI based Integration Flow generation with mediation steps should surely increase the integration flow developer efficiency.

entry.title: Re: Crystal Reports application pool crashes 5011, 1000 W...
entry.content:
SP 33 is quite old, upgrade to SP 38, SAP only supports the latest SP, you can get it from here:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SUPPORT_CONTENT/crystalreports/3354091173.html?locale=en-US

Also, CR for VS only supports 4.7 and 4.8 Framework, 4.5 is quite old and no longer supported by Microsoft.

Check the CR for VS Platform supported here:

https://www.sap.com/documents/2016/06/f871031e-757c-0010-82c7-eda71af511fa.html

Those errors are being generated by IIS, not CR error codes.

A quick Google search for IIS errors suggested this:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/466375/was-event-id-5011

IIS Error 5011, reported as a Warning in the System Event Log with the source "Microsoft-Windows-WAS" (Windows Process Activation Service), indicates that an application pool process suffered a fatal communication error with WAS. This typically leads to the application pool crashing or restarting.
 
 
Common Causes:
 
 
  • Resource Exhaustion:
    Insufficient CPU, memory, or disk resources can cause the application pool process to become unresponsive and lose communication with WAS.
  • Third-Party Software Conflicts:
    Backup agents, antivirus software, or other third-party applications can interfere with IIS processes and cause crashes.
  • Expired Certificates:
    In Exchange Server environments, an expired OAuth certificate can lead to application pool crashes.
  • Application Pool Configuration Issues:
    Incorrect identity settings for the application pool or other misconfigurations can cause instability.
  • Unhandled Exceptions or Crashes within the Application:
    Errors within the web application itself (e.g., unhandled exceptions, memory leaks, or native code issues) can lead to the process crashing.
     
  •  
Troubleshooting Steps:
 
 
  • Check Event Viewer:
    Examine the System and Application logs in Event Viewer for Event ID 5011 and any related events (e.g., 15004-15007) that might provide more specific error details or clues about the cause.
  • Monitor Resource Utilization:
    Use Performance Monitor or Process Explorer to track CPU, memory, and disk usage at the time of the crashes to identify potential resource bottlenecks.
  • Recycle the Application Pool:
    As a temporary measure, recycle the affected application pool from IIS Manager to see if it stabilizes the service.
  • Review Application Pool Identity:
    Verify the identity configured for the application pool in IIS Manager and ensure it has the necessary permissions. Re-applying the identity settings can sometimes resolve issues.
  • Check for Third-Party Software Conflicts:
    Temporarily disable or uninstall any recently installed backup or antivirus software to see if it resolves the issue.
  • Verify Certificates:
    If applicable (e.g., Exchange Server), check the validity of any relevant certificates, such as the OAuth certificate.
  • Analyze Crash Dumps:
    If the issue persists and involves consistent crashes, consider configuring IIS to generate crash dumps and analyze them with tools like Windbg to identify the root cause within the application or its dependencies.

entry.title: Applying 'Techncial User Propagation' to API Management
entry.content:
1. Introduction:

In the previous blog, we explored how technical user propagation works in SAP Integration Suite / Cloud Integration using the OData V2, SOAP, and HTTP receiver adapters. In this installment, we turn our attention to API Management, where the on-premise proxy component plays a crucial role in securely bridging cloud-hosted APIs with on-premise systems. Much like Cloud Integration, the question of propagating a fixed technical identity comes up frequently here — but the mechanisms and configuration steps differ.

2. Quick recap on on-premise connectivity in API Management:

Before diving deeper, let’s briefly review how API Management handles connectivity to on-premise systems. Within the API Provider settings, API Management supports the concept of Principal Propagation. This means that when a request is forwarded to an on-premise system, the expectation is that a valid user session (or principal) already exists — typically established via mechanisms such as SSO / token exchange.

Under the hood, the On-premise proxy component in API Management uses the BTP Destination as the connectivity anchor. The authenticated user session is propagated to this destination, which in turn leverages the Cloud Connector to securely tunnel the call into the corporate network. Finally, at the backend system level, the X.509 certificate mechanism comes into play, mapping the propagated principal to the appropriate backend user. We described this process in our previous blog.

3. Concrete example – Entra ID & token exchange:

In practice, many customers authenticate users against Identity Provider systems such as Entra ID (formerly Azure AD). In this flow, Entra ID issues a JWT token where the user subject (often the user’s email ID) is included as a claim. This JWT is then presented to API Management, which, after an optional verification step, in turn exchanges it with XSUAA using the OAuth2 SAML Assertion flow. The result is an XSUAA-issued token that the on-premise proxy component in API Management can securely propagate downstream. This pattern is widely adopted and serves as the backbone of many user-centric API Management scenarios.

Note: There are many excellent SAP Community blogs that go into great detail about this token handshake and its variants. To keep our focus sharp, we won’t recap those here — instead, we’ll stay aligned with the specific objective of this blog: exploring how technical user propagation scenarios can be addressed in API Management’s On-Premise proxy component.

4. From user sessions to technical credentials:

While the model described above works seamlessly for user-centric flows, many integration patterns require a fixed technical credential instead. This is where customers start looking for approaches similar to the one we highlighted in Cloud Integration, where technical user propagation can be achieved by leveraging the 'SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication' header. With API Management’s on-premise proxy component, patterns are available to achieve secure technical identity propagation, which differ slightly from the one we highlighted for Cloud Integration.

5. Usage scenarios with API Management:

To make this blog post engaging, we would like to introduce multiple patterns of usage, since there is no single “gold standard”  for implementing authentication in API Management. The right choice depends on the system landscape, security requirements, and integration goals. Below, we outline a few practical scenarios that illustrate different approaches. You are free to adjust the scenario based on your security needs:

1. JWT Bearer Token injection (Client credentials authentication):

In this scenario, the client is responsible for obtaining an access token itself. This typically involves the client exchanging its client credentials of API Management's on-premise proxy component for a JWT access token and presenting it as part of the API call. API Management then processes this token and propagates the corresponding identity further downstream through the destination, Cloud Connector, and finally to the backend.

Note: While this approach is relatively straightforward, it places the responsibility of managing OAuth credentials and tokens directly on the client. Therefore, it should not be relied upon as the sole security mechanism. It is strongly recommended to validate the JWT on the API Management layer (or downstream) and ensure that it contains the expected claims (such as issuer, audience, scope, or custom claims like the target client_id) before granting access. This ensures that the token has not only been issued by BTP's XSUAA  but also carries the correct authorization context for your APIs.

Pre-requisite(s):

Make sure that you have created a service instance of the 'API Management, API portal'  service with the 'on-premise-connectivity' service plan.

2. API Key injection (Credential abstraction for clients):

In this setup, the client application supplies an API Key when calling API Management in addition to any other security mechanism. Behind the scenes, the API Proxy is configured to exchange fixed technical credentials with the Identity Provider (BTP XSUAA) to obtain an access token. This approach helps ensure that the sensitive technical credentials — the ones that need to be propagated — remain hidden from the client, thereby strengthening security.

To make matters more interesting, in our walkthrough, we will not rely on a basic client credentials grant type. Instead, we will demonstrate a certificate-based token exchange, where API Management presents a client certificate to XSUAA (via OAuth2 with mutual TLS) to obtain the token. This pattern is increasingly popular in enterprise landscapes because it provides stronger binding between client identity and issued tokens (RFC 8705), without ever exposing the client secret, while still abstracting the complexity from the consuming client.

Pre-requisite(s):

a) Ensure that the Developer Hub is enabled and that you can create product subscriptions.

b) Ensure you have a service key enabled for X.509 certificate authentication. Copy the generated client_id. You can follow this guide to set it up, and then refer to step 3.3 in our previous article to create a PFX/P12 file that bundles the certificate and key together.

c) Ensure that the PFX file is uploaded to a keystore from the 'Certificates' section.

3. Client Certificate-based Authentication:

In this scenario, the consuming client application presents an external client certificate directly to the API Management runtime when invoking an API. The API Management host validates the certificate against its trust store and, based on pre-configured certificate-to-credential mapping, resolves the call to a fixed technical credential.

This design is particularly useful in system-to-system integrations where client identities are represented by certificates instead of (/in addition to) tokens or API Keys, as the certificate itself acts as the authentication factor. Internally, the mapped technical user is then propagated through to the BTP Destination, Cloud Connector, and ultimately to the backend system using the same mechanisms as in the earlier scenarios.

Note: This approach is especially appealing when clients cannot (or should not) handle OAuth flows, but are capable of securely storing and presenting a client certificate. However, it requires careful lifecycle management of certificates (renewal, rotation, and trust configuration) to ensure uninterrupted connectivity.

Pre-requisite(s):

  1. Make sure you are configured for certificate-based authentication. You can then manage your clients’ certificate chains in the Trust Store as a convenient self-service feature.
  2.  Ensure you can read the 'ConnectionProperties' and 'ClientProperties' property variables. You will need to create an operations ticket to do so. 

Let’s examine each of these scenarios in detail. Please note that this is not a step-by-step guide; rather, we will focus on highlighting only the key steps.

6. Scenario#1 (Client credentials Authentication) - API Provider and Proxy configurations:

Let’s review the essential API Provider and Proxy configurations required to enable propagation of the 'SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication' header.

1. Create an Extract Variable policy like so (typically on the 'PreFlow' step) to extract the JWT token from the Authorization request and store it in a variable to be referenced later.

<!-- Extract content from the request or response messages, including headers, URI paths, JSON/XML payloads, form parameters, and query parameters -->
<ExtractVariables async="true" continueOnError="false" enabled="false" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<Header name="Authorization">
        <Pattern ignoreCase="true">Bearer {sapapim.jwt}</Pattern>
    </Header>
    <IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>true</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<Source>request</Source>
</ExtractVariables>

2. After this step, use a Verify JWT policy to verify the signatures on the JWT as well as any standard and custom claims. Follow this blog series to learn more about JWT verification capabilities.

<!-- Verify JWT TOken -->
<VerifyJWT async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
    <Algorithm>RS256</Algorithm>
    <Source>sapapim.jwt</Source>
    <PublicKey>
            <Value ref="jwt.publickey"/>
    </PublicKey>
    <Subject ref="apim.subject"/>
    <Issuer ref="apim.issuer"/>
    <Audience ref="apim.issuer"/>
    <AdditionalClaims>
    </AdditionalClaims>
</VerifyJWT>

3. Next, create an AssignMessage policy like so to inject the 'SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication' header with the variable captured from the previous step, and make sure to remove the 'Authorization' header.

<!-- This policy can be used to create or modify the standard HTTP request and response messages -->
<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<Remove>
		<Headers>
		     <Header name="Authorization"></Header>
		</Headers>
	</Remove>
	<Set>
		<Headers>
		     <Header name="SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication">Bearer {sapapim.accessToken}</Header>
		</Headers>
	</Set> 
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<AssignTo createNew="false" type="request">request</AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

 4. Finally, ensure that the API Provider’s authentication setting is configured as None rather than Principal Propagation. This is the very configuration we applied for the SOAP Adapter scenario discussed in the previous blog post.

5. Let's get down to testing now. The first step would be to get an access token from the authorization server's (XSUAA) token endpoint.

curl --location --request POST 'https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token' \
  --header 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' \
  --user '<client_id>:<client_secret>' \
  --data-urlencode 'grant_type=client_credentials'

6. Copy the access token from the result of the call above and invoke the API Proxy by presenting the Bearer token in the Authorization header.

curl --location --request GET 'https://<apim_base_url>/<your_api_path>' \
  --header "Authorization: Bearer <access_token>"

✅ Assuming that the rest of your configurations are intact, the call should complete successfully and return the expected backend records.

7. To validate the token handshake and X.509 certificate generation, refer to the verification steps detailed in Step 4.1 in our linked blog post.

7. Scenario#2 (APIKey injection) - Proxy configuration:

In this scenario, the client credentials will not be exposed directly to the client. Instead, we inject the required client_id as a custom attribute within the Product Subscription. During runtime, this identifier is dynamically retrieved via a policy and used to obtain an access token from the authorization server

1. Log in to your Developer Hub, create a product subscription for your target API. Navigate to the Custom Attribute tab and create an attribute called 'x_client_id' and place the client_id copied from step 2.b. as the Value. 

2. You may choose to follow the same workflow demonstrated in Scenario 1. In addition, an important step is to configure the Verify API Key policy, for example, in the PreFlow segment.

 <!--Specify in the APIKey element where to look for the variable containing the api key--> 
<VerifyAPIKey async='true' continueOnError='false' enabled='true' 
xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<APIKey ref='request.header.apikey'/>
</VerifyAPIKey>

3. Next, add an AccessEntity policy to get hold of a reference to the 'application's' attributes.

<!-- this policy can be used to retrieve all details of an entity(application, API Product, company, company developer, consumer key and developer) -->
<AccessEntity async="true" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<!-- the name of the type of entity to be retrieved -->
	<EntityType value="app"/>
	<!-- The value that identifies the specific entity whose profile should be retrieved. The ref attribute identifies the variable that provides the source of the identifier. 
	The type identifies the EntityType populated by the referenced variable -->
	<EntityIdentifier ref="request.header.apikey" type="consumerkey"/>
</AccessEntity>

4. Then add an ExtractVariable policy to parse and extract the value of the custom attribute defined in the previous step.

<!-- Extract content from the request or response messages, including headers, URI paths, JSON/XML payloads, form parameters, and query parameters -->
<ExtractVariables async="true" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<!-- the source variable which should be parsed -->
	<Source>AccessEntity.name-of-the-AccessEntity-policy-here</Source>
	<!-- Specifies the XML-formatted message from which the value of the variable will be extracted -->
	<XMLPayload>
    	<!-- Specifies variable to which the extracted value will be assigned -->
    	<Variable name="x-client-id" type="string">
    		<!-- Specifies the XPath defined for the variable -->
    		<XPath>/App/Attributes/Attribute[Name='x_client_id']/Value/text()</XPath>
   	    </Variable>
	</XMLPayload>
</ExtractVariables>

5. After this step, we add a small script to construct the URL-encoded form payload in preparation for the token retrieval step. Notice that we have not used the client secret attribute at all. 

function getFormElement(name,value){
    return name + "=" + encodeURIComponent(value);
}

function createOAuthRequest(){
    return getFormElement("grant_type","client_credentials")
                + "&" + getFormElement("client_id", context.getVariable("x-client-id")) ;
}

context.setVariable("sapapim.tokenRequest", createOAuthRequest());

6. We will follow this up with a ServiceCallout policy to make a POST request to the '.cert...' token endpoint. Notice that we are attaching the certificate of the service key retrieved in step 2.c. by referencing it from the keystore.

<ServiceCallout async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
    <Request clearPayload="true">
        <Set>
            <Payload contentType="application/x-www-form-urlencoded">{sapapim.tokenRequest}</Payload>
            <Verb>POST</Verb>
        </Set>
        <IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
    </Request>
    <Response>sapapim.tokenResponse</Response>
    <Timeout>30000</Timeout>
    <HTTPTargetConnection>
        <URL>https://<tenant-dentifier>.authentication.cert.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token</URL>
        <SSLInfo> 
                 <Enabled>true</Enabled> 
                <ClientAuthEnabled>true</ClientAuthEnabled> 
                <KeyStore>KEYSTORE-NAME-GOES-HERE</KeyStore> 
                <KeyAlias>CERTIFICATE-NAME-GOES-HERE</KeyAlias> 
        </SSLInfo>
    </HTTPTargetConnection>
</ServiceCallout>

7. Finally, retrieve the access token and attach it to the SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication header, as demonstrated in step 3 of scenario 1.

8. To test this setup, modify the curl command from scenario 1 to add the APIKey header attribute, like so:

curl --location --request GET 'https://<apim_base_url>/<your_api_path>' \ 
--header "APIKey: <your_api_key>"

8. Scenario#3 (Client certificate-based authentication) - Proxy configuration:

The critical security step in this scenario is that the client presents its certificate, which API Management validates against the trusted certificates stored in its Trust Store. This validation ensures that only clients with a recognized and trusted certificate can establish communication, thereby guaranteeing both authenticity and trust in the interaction.

When the 'ConnectionProperties' and 'ClientProperties' attributes are enabled, as described in the prerequisites section, you can also access key certificate details such as the Issuer DN and Client CN. For this scenario, we assume that the API Administrator maintains an access control list mapping a predefined set of certificate Common Names to unique client_ids. This ensures that the technical identifier is propagated only when a matching client certificate is presented. 

Let's set this up.

1. Create a Key Value Map and maintain a table mapping the common name of the client to the designated client_id. 

2. Construct a KeyValueMapOperations policy that dynamically retrieves the 'tls.client.s.dn' property from the presented certificate, looks up the Key Value Map created in the above step, and assigns the value of the client_id to a variable called 'x_client_id'. 

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<KeyValueMapOperations mapIdentifier="TechnicalAuthenticationMap" async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="false" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
    <Get assignTo="x_client_id" index="1">
        <Key>
            <Parameter ref ="tls.client.s.dn"/>
        </Key>
    </Get>
    <Scope>environment</Scope>
</KeyValueMapOperations>

3. Repeat steps 5, 6, and 7 from Scenario 2 to generate an access token and assign it to the target header.

4. To test the invocation, adjust the curl command to pass the client certificate

curl --location --request GET 'https://<apim_base_url>/<your_api_path>' \
  --header "Authorization: Bearer <access_token>" \
  --header "APIKey: <your_api_key>" \
  --cert <path_to_certificate>.pfx --cert-type P12 --pass <pfx_password>

👏Congratulations on getting this far!

9. Summary:

The three API Management scenarios illustrate different approaches for technical user propagation using the SAP-Connectivity-Technical-Authentication header. In the first approach, the client directly provides credentials to obtain an access token, exposing sensitive information. The second approach leverages API Management to propagate technical credentials internally, keeping them hidden from the client and simplifying integration. The third approach uses mutual TLS and X.509 certificates to securely propagate the technical user identity from API Management through the API Provider to the backend system, ensuring end-to-end authentication without exposing internal credentials.

entry.title: Re: canada tax rates
entry.content:
Possible causes could be

  • MW5 might be marked as statistical in the tax procedure (transaction OBYZ). If a condition is statistical, it won’t allow rate entry in FTXP.
  • The condition type MW5 may not have a valid access sequence or the condition record may be locked by another user/session.

Follow the below steps to update the tax rate


  • Go to transaction OBYZ, select your Canadian tax procedure (e.g., TAXCAJ). Find MW5 and ensure Statistical checkbox is not selected, Calculation type is correct (usually percentage). Condition class is set appropriately (usually class D for taxes).
  • Go to SCC4, ensure the client allows changes to cross-client customizing. If not, coordinate with your BASIS team to temporarily open it.
  • Go to transaction FTXP, select Country = CA, Tax Code = N1 or N2, enter the validity period, ppdate the MW5 rate (e.g., 5.00%). Save the changes.

Additionally,

  • If you're using jurisdiction-based tax, ensure the jurisdiction codes are correctly mapped and active
  • For input tax codes, verify that MW5 is assigned to the correct account key (e.g., VST)
  • If you're using condition-based tax determination, check the access sequence and condition records via VK13

entry.title: Re: Automated tender/RFP management for supplier - multin...
entry.content: SAP Ariba will handle as a supplier portal, and is great for identification / discovery of tenders/RFPs for suppliers. But it won't necessarily help with evaluation and responding to tenders/RFPs. There's numerous RFP response Software that work in portal such as SAP Ariba. Those include AutoRFP, Responsive, Loopio etc. For submitting RFPs, you may interact with SAP Ariba via the portal, but many RFPs will come in word doc/excel. In that case your RFP automation software (e.g. AutoRFP.ai etc mentioned above) will help with auto fill of RFP requirements based on your past RFPs and documentation.

entry.title: Re: Payment Block not working in FB60 even though Manual...
entry.content:
While the blog shared here, gives a comprehensive overview of payment block types, their configuration, and how they behave across different transactions — especially in payment execution and invoice verification, you need to understand why FB60 allows posting despite a vendor block, and how to enforce stricter behavior using validation or configuration.

SAP’s standard behavior is the payment block in the vendor master does not automatically transfer to the invoice during FB60 unless, you’ve configured a defaulting mechanism (e.g., via OBB8), Or you manually set the block during posting. The “manual payments blocked” setting in customizing only affects manual payment transactions like F-53. It prevents clearing of open items with that block. It does not prevent invoice posting in FB60. So yes — you can post invoices even if the vendor is blocked for payment. The block only affects payment execution, not invoice entry.

To default the Payment Block automatically, use transaction OBB8 to configure default payment block behavior based on Company code, Payment terms, Vendor group. This will ensure that invoices posted via FB60 inherit the block automatically.

Create a validation rule in transaction OB28 to check if vendor has block X and prevent posting unless the block is manually set on the document.

If you want stricter control, add a custom warning or error via enhancement. Train users to manually set the block during invoice entry

entry.title: How to send the notification mail for IEM once a day with the specified time
entry.content:
In FRUN system, we configured the calculating frequency of the alert for IEM(Integration & Exception Monitoring) as 1440 minutes (=24 hours) so that the alert notification is sent just once a day.
It is working fine - the alert notification is sent just once a day at around 10:50am.
Is it possible to change the time to 8:00am?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to send the notification mail for IEM once a day...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

The current design of FRUN doesn't provide the option for adjusting the time for sending an alerts.
 
The functionality you want is not provided by the SAP standard but you can try the following approach and test whether it works.
 
Basically, if the configuration of the alert was saved with a minor change (e.g. enter one more space in the alert name, etc.), it will trigger a new alert shortly thereafter.
So if you change the configuration and save it at around 7:55am, the new alert will be generated around at 8am.
However, as your configuration is already with 1440 minutes, there will be mostly data loss in the next alert instances if you just save the change around at 7:55am(or before).
 
Therefore, the better approach would be the below:

  1. Adjust the alert configuration and save it with a calculation frequency of 1265 minutes once the regular alert has been triggered at 10:55 AM.
    This adjustment will generate an additional alert shortly after the modification, capturing any new aborted jobs created between 10:55 AM and the configuration change.
    The subsequent alert will be triggered at approximately 8 AM the following day.
  2. After the alert is triggered around 8 AM the next day, revert the calculation frequency of the alert back to 1440 minutes and save the alert configuration around ~8AM (or else the next alert will be triggered 5:55am next day).
    This action will prompt one additional alert to be generated shortly thereafter capturing any new aborted jobs created between 8 AM and the configuration change.
    But this ensures all subsequent alerts are consistently triggered daily at approximately near to 8 AM.

Please test it and adjust it according your needs.

Hope above helps you.
Best regards,
SAP Support
